isis.stitle: TSI 05-09-01R - Repair Instructions for 8600 Model, Built Before November 22, 2004, Fender Extensions with Cracks Along the Rear Bottom Edge

subjectgroup.subject: Repair Instructions for 8600 Model, Built Before November 22, 2004, Fender Extensions with Cracks Along the Rear Bottom Edge

geninfo.para: The following service procedure provides instructions for the repair of fender extensions, on 8600 Models, that have cracks along the rear bottom edge of the fender extension.

entry.para: Fender Extension Mud Flap Kit Contains:

table.title: Additional Parts Depending on 8600 Model Being Serviced

warning.para: To avoid property damage, personal injury, or death, park the vehicle on a flat level surface, set the parking brake, chock the wheels, and turn the engine off.

step1.para: Inspect the entire fender extension to locate any cracks in the part. The fender extension should be wiped with moist shop towels or otherwise washed to remove as much dust and dirt as possible for this inspection. If cracks are only found in the bottom portion of the fender extension, and the end of the crack is not closer than 2.5 vertical inches above the bottom edge of the reinforcement ribs (see Figure 1), then the fender extension can be cut to receive a mud flap assembly outlined in this publication. Go to Step 2. Otherwise, cracks extending higher than a maximum of 2.5 inches vertically above the bottom of the fender extension's ribs and/or visible anywhere else on the fender extension cannot be fixed with the process outlined in this publication. These fender extensions should be otherwise repaired or replaced. Refer to the ISIS home page, suppliers tab, Fusor® for proper crack repair methods.

Temporarily apply the universal (fits either side of vehicle) mud flap-retainer strip to be used as a locating template for holes to be drilled in the lower rear portion of the fender extension. This template will also be used for drawing or scribing a cutting line on the fender extension for removal of the bottom few inches of the fender extension.
Drill located holes in the fender extension for the mud flap mounting.
Remove the bottom few inches of the fender extension, along cutting line created with the aid of the mud flap-retainer from Step 2.
Apply the mud flap assembly with fasteners and hardware provided.
Apply a wire air/fuel-tank-guard (unique guards for round fuel tanks, D-style fuel tanks, and air tanks) with fasteners and hardware provided.

para.emph: The following instructions refer to the driver's side of the vehicle.

step1.para: Remove fender extension. Clean the lower portion of the rear outer surface with a shop towel and a suitable solvent (brake cleaner used in moderation is suitable). Wipe dry with a clean shop towel.

Place the mud flap retainer on the fender extension as shown, with the larger leg pressed against the inboard surface of the fender extension and the bottom edge of the mud flap retainer 8.5 inches from the bottom edge of the fender extension (see Figure 8 below):

CLAMP the mud flap retainer in this position, leaving the slots accessible. The mud flap retainer will not fit perfectly against the fender extension at all locations along its length, and will have a noticeable gap at the end with the shorter leg near the outboard side of the fender extension. That's okay. The mud flap retainer is designed to be a template for locating cutting lines and holes, in addition to being a retainer for the mud flap. Liberal use of clamps can temporarily deform the mud flap retainer into the form of the fender extension needed for this step.
Locate the five, 9.5-millimeter (3/8-inch) mounting holes as shown in Figure 9 and Figure 10. Make sure to mark or drill on the correct side of each slot:

Pencil, scribe, or otherwise mark a line (curve) on the outer surface of the fender extension along the bottom edge of the mud flap retainer. Extend the line (curve) to the edges of the fender extension, freehand. Refer to Figure 11, below. Remove the mud flap retainer and go to Step 5.

In this step, the mud flap mounting holes (10-mm (3/8-inch) diameter, nominal) should be drilled (if they weren't already drilled in Step 3) and the bottom section of the fender extension should be cut off along the line created in Step 4. A die grinder or angle grinder equipped with a diamond impregnated cut-off wheel is the recommended tool for making this cut along the bottom of the fender extension, in order to get the best finish and require the least amount of touch-up along the bottom edge. Care should also be taken not to cut the fender extension shorter than prescribed. The cut can fall below the cut line, but DO NOT CUT ABOVE THE CUT LINE. Drill holes and remove the bottom section in whichever order is best to achieve good results and to avoid cracking the part.

The cut edge of the fender extension should be sanded smooth, with special emphasis on the "now sharp" corners where the cut surface meets the inboard and outboard edges (see Figure 12 below). After sanding, a coat of matching touch-up paint should be applied to the bottom of the fender extension.

After ample time for the touch-up paint to dry, the mud flap can be applied with the hardware provided. Each mud flap assembly will require five black stainless steel Torx bolts with thread patch, five of the stainless steel washers, and five plain (no flange) stainless steel hex nuts. Torque the fasteners to 6-8 Nm (50-70 in-lb). The mud flap-to-fender extension installation drawing is shown in Figure 13 below:

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE: FUEL TANK GUARD ATTACHMENT

para.emph:
The following steps to attach a fuel tank guard apply to the driver's side of trucks equipped with under cab D-style fuel tanks only. For trucks equipped with under cab round fuel tanks, skip to that procedure
and for trucks equipped with under cab air tanks, skip to Air Tank Guard Attachment .

step1.para: On the lower cab-access step, place the 50 mm bolt (3514723C1) in the inboard hole of the step indicated by Figure 14 below:

Place the D-style fuel tank guard (see Figure 15 below). Apply one stainless steel washer and one flange lock-nut to the 50-mm bolt on the underside of the fuel tank guard's eye. Don't torque this bolt to specification until the inboard bolt is in place.

Place the D-style fuel tank guard against the fuel-tank-to-frame mounting bracket (see Figure 16). Apply one large washer under the flange head of the 100-mm bolt and slide the bolt through the unused hole on the rear side of the forward-most fuel-tank-to-frame mounting bracket and through the inboard eye of the D-style fuel tank guard as shown in Figure 16. Place another large washer on the 100-mm bolt to face the front side of the D-style fuel tank guard's inboard eye. Apply one flange lock nut to the 100-mm bolt. Torque both D-style fuel tank guard bolts to 47-58 Nm (34-42 lbf-ft).
Re-attach the fender extension with the mud flap assembly. The finished assembly should look like Figure 17 below.

para.emph:
The following steps to attach a fuel tank guard apply to the driver's side of trucks equipped with under cab round fuel tanks only. For trucks equipped with under cab D-style fuel tanks, see Fuel Tank Guard Attachment
and for trucks equipped with under cab air tanks, see Air Tank Guard Attachment .

svcproc.para: 1. On the lower cab-access step, place the 50 mm bolt (3514723C1) in the middle hole of the step indicated by Figure 18.

2. Place the round fuel tank guard (see Figure 19 below). Place one of the washers on the bottom of the bolt against the eye of the round fuel tank guard. Finally, attach one flange lock-nut, but don't torque to specification until the inboard bolt of the fuel tank guard is in place.

3. Place the inboard eye of the round fuel tank guard against the fuel-tank-to-frame mounting bracket (see Figure 20 below). Apply one large washer under the flange head of the 100-mm bolt and slide the bolt through the unused slot on the rear side of the forward-most fuel-tank-to-frame mounting bracket and through the inboard eye of the round fuel tank guard as shown in Figure 20. Place another large washer on the 100-mm bolt to face the front side of the round fuel tank guard's inboard eye. Apply one flange lock nut to the 100-mm bolt. Torque the inboard and outboard round fuel tank guard fasteners 47-58 Nm (34-42 lbf-ft).
4. Re-attach the fender extension with the mud flap assembly. The finished assembly should look like Figure 21 below.

note.para: Passenger side component application and preparation processes are to be completed in a similar manner.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE: AIR TANK GUARD ATTACHMENT

para.emph:
The following steps to attach an air tank guard apply to the driver's side of trucks equipped with under cab air tanks only. For trucks equipped with under cab D-style fuel tanks, see Fuel Tank Guard Attachment
and for trucks equipped with under cab round fuel tanks, see that procedure .

step1.para: On the forward cab access step-to-frame mounting bracket, remove and discard the lower mounting bolt as shown in Figure 22.
On the lower cab-access step, place the 50 mm bolt (3514723C1) in the middle hole of the step indicated by Figure 23.

Place the air tank guard (see Figure 24 below). Place one of the washers on the bottom of the bolt against the eye of the air tank guard. Finally, attach one flange lock-nut, but don't torque to specification until the inboard bolt of the air tank guard is in place.

Place the inboard eye of the air tank guard against the cab access step-to-frame mounting bracket (see Figure 25 below). Replace the discarded bolt with the 40-mm bolt provided as shown in Figure 25. Torque the inboard and outboard air tank guard fasteners to 14-20 Nm (125-175 in-lb).
Re-attach the fender extension with the mud flap assembly. The finished assembly should look like Figure 26 below.
